def load_files(dirname):
    filenames = os.listdir(dirname)
    raw_files = []

    for filename in tqdm(filenames):
        filename = dirname + filename
        file = json.load(open(filename, 'rb'))
        raw_files.append(file)
    
    return raw_files

def generate_clean_df(all_files):
    cleaned_files = []
    
    for file in tqdm(all_files):
        features = [
            file['paper_id'],
            file['metadata']['title'],
            format_authors(file['metadata']['authors']),
            format_authors(file['metadata']['authors'], 
                           with_affiliation=True),
            format_body(file['abstract']),
            format_body(file['body_text']),
            format_bib(file['bib_entries']),
            file['metadata']['authors'],
            file['bib_entries']
        ]

        cleaned_files.append(features)

    col_names = ['paper_id', 'title', 'authors',
                 'affiliations', 'abstract', 'text', 
                 'bibliography','raw_authors','raw_bibliography']

    clean_df = pd.DataFrame(cleaned_files, columns=col_names)
    clean_df.head()
    
    return clean_df

import gensim

def read_corpus(df, column, tokens_only=False):
    """
    Arguments
    ---------
        df: pd.DataFrame
        column: str 
            text column name
        tokens_only: bool
            wether to add tags or not
    """
    for i, line in enumerate(df[column]):

        tokens = gensim.parsing.preprocess_string(line)
        if tokens_only:
            yield tokens
        else:
            # For training data, add tags
            yield gensim.models.doc2vec.TaggedDocument(tokens, [i])

source.03a2a649: ## 2. Train gensim Doc2Vec model Word2Vec is a very famous algorithm for word embeddings. You can find a very good explanation of this algorithm in [this amazing blog post](http://jalammar.github.io/illustrated-word2vec/) The main idea is beautifully resumed in this quote by [John Ruper Firth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Rupert_Firth) : *You shall know a word by the company it keeps* Word2Vec came up with this very innovative idea where you train a neural network on a task (finding a word given surrounding words - or the reverse) but you are not interested in the result of this task, rather in the weights of the network’s hidden layer, that will be used to derive the word vectors. Doc2Vec has an augmented objective to have one vector for a sequence of words. The first idea to do that could be to just take the mean vector of the Word2Vec vectors of each word in the sequence, however the Doc2Vec authors had a smarter idea ([see the paper here](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1405.4053v2.pdf)) ). It follows the same principle as Word2Vec : training on a task to get the hidden layer as a vector, but this time, we add the whole paragraph matrix along the window words as an input to the classifier. See on the following figure the task for the distributed memory model (you can check the other algorithm : Distributed bag of words in the article) Fortunately the famous NLP library Gensim comes with an optimized class to train the Doc2Vec model [We can follow this tutorial](https://radimrehurek.com/gensim/auto_examples/tutorials/run_doc2vec_lee.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-tutorials-run-doc2vec-lee-py) on training Doc2Vec with gensim

## About this notebook
The helper functions are taken from here : https://www.kaggle.com/xhlulu/cord-19-eda-parse-json-and-generate-clean-csv
(Many thanks to @xhlulu for the convenient pre-treatment)

The goal of this notebook is to present a methodology to find match between the articles and the tasks descriptions, and to have a visual representation of the rlationship between tasks and articles

### Summary

#### 1. [Loading data](#helper)
Using @xhlulu's work 
#### 2. [Doc2Vec training on abstracts data](#train)
Train Gensim Doc2Vec model on abstracts 
#### 2. [Doc2Vec projection of tasks](#tasks)  
   Use the model to convert tasks and abstracts to vectors
#### 3. [Nearest Neighbors analysis](#search)
   Find which abstracts are closest to each task description
#### 4. [Clustering and PCA + UMAP to visualise abstract and texts in a 3D space](#clustering)
   Use the vectors to perform a clustering (K-Means) and then use PCA + UMAP to reduce dimension to 3 and visualize the results 




Find out more on this blog post : https://www.quantmetry.com/kaggle-covid-19-open-research-dataset-challenge-cord-19/
